item.title: Inside Europe 03.11.2022
item.description: A conversation with British immigration lawyer Colin Yeo, Serbs and Kosovans at loggerheads over numberplates, Turkey holds Sweden’s fate in its hands, plus the Kyiv City Ballet in Paris. Also: Germany’s domestic intelligence agency has questions to answer, Swiss glaciers feel the heat, Ukraine’s tourist industry attempts a comeback, and Albania’s medicinal herb sector faces limits to growth.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Kate Laycock, NSU, immigration, melting glaciers, Kosovo

item.title: Inside Europe 27.10.2022
item.description: The UK gets its third Prime Minister in three months, Kazakhstan becomes a safe haven for companies fleeing sanctions, and France finds new use for its agricultural waste. Also: Ilya Matveev dares to imagine Russia without Putin, a double homicide spotlights homophobia in Slovakia, the Vatican has questions to answer, and Halloween comes to Germany.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Europe, Adam Boulton, Ilya Matveev, Kazakhstan

item.title: Inside Europe 20.10.2022
item.description: Russian troops arrive for joint military operations in Belarus, distressing scenes at the Greek-Turkish border, and German bakers struggle to cope with rising energy prices. Also: The Netherlands withdraws from the Energy Charter Treaty, we stay close to the ground in both Ljubljana and Sofia, and ring out to the sound of Mechelen’s medieval carillon bells.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe podcast, Belarus, Sofia, Ljubljana

item.title: Inside Europe 13.10.2022
item.description: NATO members ask if boosting Ukraine's air defense threatens their own security, a digital summit in Estonia lauds “trusted connectivity” amid growing cyber threats, housing asylum seekers on cruise ships in the Netherlands stirs anger, and religious education in Poland loses its appeal. Also; our environment podcast On the Green Fence asks if co-housing groups offer a low-impact way of living.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Ukraine war, NATO defense, security in Europe, low impact housing, co-op housing, religious education, Poland, asylum seekers, Netherlands, cruise ships, digital summit Estonia

item.title: Inside Europe 06.10.2022
item.description: The UK’s new prime minster makes an embarrassing climb-down, the EU risks applying double standards in its dealings with Azerbaijan, a national idol becomes the latest target in Turkey’s crackdown on dissent and Bologna celebrates its annual tortellini festival. Plus a Europe on the Move transport special looking at the ways in which European countries are future-proofing their public transport.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: transport, Inside Europe, the EU

item.title: Inside Europe 29.09.2022
item.description: The psychology of resistance in Russia, the politics of remembrance in Poland and the rule of law in Hungary. Also: Ukrainian environmentalist Svitlana Romanko responds to the North Stream gas leaks, Turkey’s recycling industry and the people it exploits, why the Danube is no longer blue and the new fossil fuel registry revolutionising carbon accountability.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Kate Laycock, Russia, environment, Danube, Auschwitz, North Stream

item.title: Inside Europe: 22.09.2022
item.description: What does Russia’s military escalation mean for Ukraine and its allies? The Estonian town with a Russian twin across the river, and after Sweden's lurch to the right, Europe awaits Italy's election results. Also: An immigration lawyer imagines Paddington Bear as his client, why Albanians can't wait to leave the country, and Eco Opera — where birds can play musical instruments.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Russian mobilization, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Albania emigration, Italy election, Giorgia Meloni, far-right politics, Russian expatriates, Estonia, Paddington Bear, migration, Oktoberfest, economic cooperation

item.title: Inside Europe: 15.09.2022
item.description: Ukraine recaptures vast swathes of territory from Russia, Belarusian exiles in Poland support Kyiv over the war, and the Brussels terror attacks trial begins. Also: Why the former Czech prime minister is in the dock and Britain mourns an iconic monarch.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Helen Seeney, Ukraine war, Kharkiv, Queen Elizabeth II, Brussels terror attacks, Italy elections, Giorgia Meloni, Andrej Babis, Belarusian dissidents, Maelbeek

item.title: Inside Europe: 08.09.2022
item.description: The UK has a new prime minister, but is everyone really sitting in the same boat? Anatomy of an airstrike: what happened at 8.35 am on March 29th, 2022? Nothing to see here: the spyware scandal causing embarrassment for the EU, and motorbike lovers beware: Paris is no longer the free ride you thought it was.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Truth Hounds, war crimes, Liz Truss, Paris

item.title: Inside Europe 01.09.2022
item.description: The EU makes it harder for Russians to get travel visas, will Russians ever forgive Mikhail Gorbachev for the collapse of the Soviet Union? Also: Ukraine prints money to pay its soldiers, Bulgarians struggle with soaring energy prices and the victims of the 2016 Nice attack could soon see justice.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Ukraine war, Ukraine economy, Russians in Turkey, Russian expatriates, EU visa rules, Bulgaria, energy crisis, Mikhail Gorbachev, fall of Soviet Union, Essen, European Green Capital, Nice attack

item.title: Inside Europe 25.08.2022
item.description: Ukrainian writer Andrei Kurkov on six months of war with Russia, Turkey’s high risk strategy continues to pay off and who killed Darya Dugina and why? Also: Afghans remain stuck in a US base in Kosovo, explore the legacy of COVID in Spain and also on the Edinburgh Fringe comedy circuit!
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Ukraine war, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Turkey as mediator, long COVID, fish die-off, Oder River, Darya Dugina, Afghan refugees, Kosovo

item.title: Inside Europe 18.08.2022
item.description: Climate special: the European Space Agency tracks terrestrial changes from space, drought in the UK, France’s nuclear conundrum and the race to contain Europe's wildfires. Also: DW's On the Green Fence podcast takes an in-depth look at the aviation industry’s contributions to climate change.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: climate, wildfires, Drought, nuclear, Kate Laycock, Inside Europe, European Space Agency (ESA)

item.title: Inside Europe 11.08.2022
item.description: How Finland's radioactive waste should be safe for 100,000 years, the UK shuts its only gender identity clinic for children, and a Slovakian council digs in over the renaming of a street. Also: 30 years on, the victims of the war in Abkhazia still seek justice, Italian long-COVID sufferers learn how to smell again and meet the Edinburgh fringe comedian who performed to an audience of one.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Nik Martin, gender identity, Tavistock clinic, Ukraine war, Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, nuclear waste dump, French wine, Josef Tiso, puberty blockers, Georgia, Abkhazia, long COVID, sense of smell, sense of taste

item.title: Inside Europe 04.08.2022
item.description: Security expert William Alberque on nuclear threats and Ukraine, Turkey expects payback for brokering Ukrainian grain deal, and England’s lionesses win the Euro Championships. Also: Russia’s war with Ukraine awakens traumatic memories for Estonians, how low water levels in the river Rhine are contributing to rising prices and a look at the human toll of the cost of living crisis.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Kate Laycock, William Alberque, nuclear, Ukraine, football, Estonia

item.title: Inside Europe 28.07.22
item.description: Moscow now wants regime change in Ukraine, we meet the Russian dissidents creating a new life in Georgia, and EU countries agree to cut their gas use. Also: how the monkeypox outbreak is stirring memories of HIV stigmatization, the Spanish island of La Palma recalls last year's volcanic eruption, and avoiding Europe's flight chaos, but will taking the train be any better?
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Nik Martin, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Kherson, Europe gas crisis, Russian dissidents, La Palma eruption, volcano, UK travel chaos, rail travel

item.title: Inside Europe 21.07.22
item.description: Climate change brings more extreme weather to Europe, Hungary's tax reforms spark public protests, and Paris hopes to stage the 2024 Olympics without blowing the budget. Also: newcomers to Italy build their culinary confidence, the threat to Europe from the new Centaurus COVID variant, and the campaign to give the UK's Cornwall county more powers.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Nik Martin, Inside Europe, climate change, European heat wave, Hungary rule of law, press freedom, Turkey, 2024 Paris Olympics, Cornwall, autonomy, Italy migrants, centaurus variant, COVID-19

item.title: Inside Europe 14.07.2022
item.description: The race to replace Boris Johnson as the UK’s next prime minister, Germans worry about freezing this winter, and why some of those canned tomatoes from Italy are so cheap. Also: meet the American actor who left Hollywood to become lord of Downton Shabby and how the Isle of Skye’s natural wonders are both a blessing and a curse.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Helen Seeney, Boris Johnson, Conservative Party leader, Germany heating costs, energy crisis, Downton Shabby, canned tomatoes, Yazidi refugees, migrant workers, Isle of Skye

item.title: Inside Europe 07.07.22
item.description: Boris Johnson resigns, a Marshall Plan for the Ukraine, an audience with the Pope and a golden opportunity for French farmers. Also: Timothy Snyder's lessons from the past, a Ukrainian CEO tackles Putin with porn, plus music from the Budapest Gypsy Symphony Orchestra.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Inside Europe podcast, Boris Johnson, Adam Boulton, pornography, Ukraine War, gypsy music

item.title: Inside Europe 30.06.2022
item.description: NATO's rapid renewal but will it deter Putin? A food crisis looms – can enough of Ukraine's grain bypass the Black Sea? Commemorative chimes: remembering the Czech church bells stolen by the Nazis. Why Europe's airlines are struggling to get airborne. Meet the Dutch firm that's building bridges from crops. And how Italians are getting a taste for Chinese fine wine. All that and more..
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Nik Martin, Inside Europe, NATO, food security, Bataclan, Ukraine, aviation industry, western Balkans, Chinese wine

item.title: Inside Europe 23.06.2022
item.description: Election fallout in France, Dutch farmers protest livestock cuts to curb nitrogen, plus a report from the world’s longest running design Biennale in Ljubljana. Also: DW honors the last journalists in Mariupol, Spain plans legislation improving women’s access to abortion, Belgium reckons with its colonial past, plus a look at France’s trailblazing face-mask recycling project.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Kate Laycock, French elections, Agriculture, Mariupol, photojournalism, Global Media Forum

item.title: Inside Europe 16.06.2022
item.description: The UK’s attempt to offshore asylum seekers to Rwanda is thwarted, Poland introduces an electronic register of pregnancies, and another round of NATO talks brings another round of military pledges. Also: an in-depth look at the topic of water - where it’s lacking, who is profiting from its scarcity and what could be done to distribute it more fairly, plus some Aboriginal jazz.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Kate Laycock, Rwanda, drought, climate change, abortion, poland, nato

item.title: Inside Europe 09.06.2022
item.description: The urgency to unblock Ukraine’s grain exports: Turkey and Poland step up efforts to stave off global food insecurity. Also, can digital nomads keep Venice afloat? An environmentally friendly car that’s cheap and assembling it is child’s play. The Russian journalists who’ve fled to Latvia. From acclaim to obscurity, the Australian violinist who inspired Europe’s composers 100 years ago. And more
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Helen Seeney, Ukrainian grain, Venice, gazelle, Russian media, Ukrainian refugees, alma moodie, Lithuanian, climate change

item.title: Inside Europe 02.06.2022
item.description: 100 days of war crimes, a month of record inflation and 70 years of Queen Elizabeth II. Also on Inside Europe: how Ukraine’s president is harnessing social media to frame the narrative of war, Serbia plays a dangerous game, Greece and Turkey defend their territorial claims and the beautiful game turns ugly: what went wrong at the UEFA Champions League final?
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: inside europe, Inside Europe podcast, Ethan Zuckermann, jubilee, war crimes, Kate Laycock

item.title: Inside Europe 26.05.2022
item.description: Ukrainians from Mariupol go through Russian filtration camps - Erdogan vows to send home Syrian refugees in Turkey - Burkinis continue to cause a stir in France - England's dental deserts - On the trail of Martin Luther - A new sustainable source of protein for our plates - And more...
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Nik Martin, filtration camp, Syrian refugees, burkini, seaweed, Martin Luther, King Juan Carlos, dental care

item.title: Inside Europe 19.05.2022
item.description: Finland and Sweden join NATO, Turkey’s president raises objections, a conversation with Human Rights Watch, and a French film with a message. Also: Kalush Orchestra return to Ukraine after winning Eurovision, Ukrainian children struggle with the German school system, a new front opens up in the UK’s so-called “culture wars”, and pangolin diplomacy in the Czech Republic.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: inside europe, Inside Europe podcast, Eurovision Song Contest, Human Rights Watch, Turkey, NATO, Finland, Sweden

item.title: Inside Europe 12.05.2022
item.description: Breaking down the psychology of Russian propaganda, testing the depths of Swiss disaster planning, unpacking Northern Ireland's historic election results. Also: challenges to the EU’s ban on Russian oil imports, a conversation with the podcaster giving voice to the Russia-German community and the Berlin Philharmonic’s Karajan Academy turns 50.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Kate Laycock, Eamonn McCann, Maxim Ayukov, Ira Peters, Russlanddeutsche, Sinn Fein, Northern Ireland, Inside Europe

item.title: Inside Europe 05.05.2022
item.description: EU bans Russian oil, Poland struggles with rule-of-law funding cuts, Slovakia’s former PM is accused of forming a criminal organisation and British Sign Language gets official recognition. Also: trauma therapy for Ukrainian refugees, Russian exiles in Turkey, a wind-turbine controversy in Normandy and Ibiza gives climate change top billing.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: EU, Oil, Russian oil, Robert Fico, sign language, Ibiza, Kate Laycock, Inside Europe podcast

item.title: Inside Europe 28.04.2022
item.description: Russia cuts off gas to Poland and Bulgaria, Ukrainian mayors appeal for reconstruction aid, and elections in France and Slovenia – we look at what the results might mean. Also on Inside Europe: leading lawyer Philippe Sands on prosecuting Putin for the crime of aggression, a look at the dilemmas facing Turkey’s drone industry and an evening in the company of Kyiv’s courageous symphony orchestra.
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Kate Laycock, Philippe Sands, Vitali Klitschko, Teri Schulz, French elections, Slowenia, Freedom Party, Drones, Inside Europe

item.title: Inside Europe 21.04.2022
item.description: Critics slam the UK’S plans to send asylum seekers to Rwanda - The German chancellor under fire over weapons for Ukraine - Concern in Moldova that it, too, is in Russia’s crosshairs - Protests in Turkey as the authorities seek to silence a women’s rights group - And On the Green Fence: How clean is the River Rhine
item.itunes:author: DW.COM | Deutsche Welle
item.itunes:keywords: Inside Europe, Helen Seeney, Ukraine war, asylum seekers, UK, Rwanda, Rhine River, Turkey femicide, Moldova, Olaf Scholz

item.title: Inside Europe 14.04.22
item.description: Uneasy deja-vu in France, war crimes in Ukraine, football as therapy and ordinary people open their homes to refugees. Also: Boris Johnson is fined for breaking his own lockdown rules, Turkey’s doctors leave the country, a journey into the politically charged world of Spanish matadors, plus a wee dram of climate vulnerable Scotch whiskey.
